awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Dynamics of repulsion and reinforcement in point process, latent variable, and trajectory models
awd_abstract_narration:
Most traditional ways of analyzing data assume that data points are sampled independently of one another.  In many problems, however, this assumption is incorrect.  This project focuses on data where one observation influences others, either as reinforcing (likely to have a similar value) or repulsing (likely to have a greatly different value). Such interactions might arise between static measurements, between trajectories evolving in space/on a network, or may be desirable biases in algorithms to promote goals like robustness, diversity or fairness. These might arise as a consequence of competition for finite resources, because of rich-get-richer dynamics from propagating social influence, because of interacting processes in physical and biological systems, or out of a desire to learn compact representations of complex systems. Examples include the locations of cells or service stations, interactions among particles or populations, traffic trajectories, users navigating social media, the spiking of neurons or the spread of disease. The research brings together applied problems and theoretical ideas from fields like machine learning, statistics, physics and computer science. Such tools open new avenues to data-summarization, exploration and visualization, and allow practitioners to explore trade-offs between interpretability and predictive accuracy. The applied aspects of this project provide an opportunity for undergraduate research and for the integration of research and teaching through an undergraduate course on stochastic processes and simulation.

At a technical level, this project develops principled statistical models and efficient algorithms that relax assumptions of independence among observations lying on a shared space. It considers interactions for three classes of problems: 1) point process models, 2) latent variable models and 3) trajectory models. Central to the work are two kinds of stochastic process models: the Hawkes process for reinforcement, and the Matern type-III process for repulsion. Both processes share intuitive and mechanistic generative schemes from an underlying Poisson process, whose rate is modulated by event history. This allows a framework that jointly models richer repulsive and reinforcing interactions in stationary and trajectory data. The connection with the Poisson process allows novel models and mechanisms of reinforcement and repulsion, as well as new, scalable algorithms, allowing investigations into the fundamental role of non-Poissonness in real applications. Incorporating repulsive priors into latent variables of hierarchical models also allow novel repulsive latent variable models with biases towards parsimony and interpretability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this proposal is to develop principled statistical models and efficient algorithms that relax assumptions of independence among observations lying on a shared space, with a particular focus on two kinds of interactions, repulsive and reinforcing. The outcome of this project is a range of models and algorithms to model, compute with and study such interactions. These allow practitioners to analyze data to understand if modeling such interactions are necessary, deal with computational challenges arising from such interactions, make predictions in the face of such interactions and finally, assess the quality of the data-fit resulting from deploying models with such interactions.

Work under this project developed a framework for neural network models to capture interactions between elements of set-valued measurements (the simplest example being point-pattern measurements). This improved over state-of-the-art methods that do not adequately capture interaction structure between elements of the sets, and helped unify existing models and algorithms as well as suggest approaches to extend the state-of-the-art. Follow-up work, even more impactful in terms of number of citations, has extended this to richer interaction structure represented by graph-valued measurements.

Another outcomes is a framework for goodness-of-fit testing for point process models with interactions. Such models tend to have 'intractable normalization constants', which makes testing for whether they are good descriptions of observed data very challenging. This outcome got around the issue of intractable normalizers by developing a methodology based on Stein's method. This work was selected for an oral presentation at Artificial Intelligence and Statistics (AISTATS 2019)

The intractable normalization constants referred to earlier also make computation for models with interactions challenging. Focusing on models of trajectories, work under this activity also developed exact Monte Carlo algorithms for continuous-time Markov processes, specifically Markov jump process (useful for tasks such as changepoint modeling) and stochastic differential equations (used in fields like finance and physics to model rich, mechanistic dynamics). This work exploited connections between Poisson processes and Brownian motion to develop exact Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms based on random time-discretizations, allowing a trade-off between bias, variance and computation.

Another line of work under this project led to the development of a novel class of repulsive models based on Matern repulsive point processes. While traditional mixture models assign parameters to clusters/components independently from some distribution, repulsive models force these components to be spread out, enforcing parsimony and diversity. Existing approaches result in intractable normalization constants and intractable models. The proposed approach avoids this, and includes a novel and straightforward MCMC sampler. This proposed sampler is also applicable to standard mixture models without repulsion, avoiding the need for challenging reversible-jump MCMC methods to estimating the number of mixture components.

Work under this grant has been carried out with 9 PhD students at Purdue. All have manuscripts submitted under this project, all but two have these manuscripts published at peer-reviewed venues. 7 have graduated with PhD degrees. Material from this projet has been incorporated into courses taught by the PI both at the graduate and undergraduate level.
